details.title: Point and interval estimation for Gaussian distribution, based on progressively Type-II censored samples
details.standardTitle: Point and interval estimation for Gaussian distribution, based on progressively Type-II censored samples

p: N. Balakrishnan is a Professor of Statistics at McMaster University, Hamilton, Canada. He received the B.Sc. in 1976 and the M.Sc. in 1978 in Statistics from the University of Madras, Tamil Nadu, and the Ph.D. in 1981 in Statistics from the Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur. His areas of interest include order statistics, estimation theory, robust inference, and classification analysis.

N. Kannan is an Associate Professor of Statistics at the University of Texas at San Antonio, USA. She received the M.A. in 1988 in Mathematics from the University of Pittsburgh, and the Ph.D. in 1992 from Penn State University. Her areas of interest include statistical signal processing, reliability theory, survival analysis, and multivariate analysis.

C. T. Lin is a Professor in the Department of Mathematics, Tamkang University, Taiwan. She received the Ph.D. in 1993 from Florida State University. Her areas of interest include reliability and applications of scan statistics.

H. K. T. Ng is an Assistant Professor in the Department of Statistical Science, Southern Methodist University, Dallas, TX, USA. He received the B.Sc. in 1997 and M.Phil. in 1999 in Statistics from the Chinese University of Hong Kong, and the M.Sc. in 2000 and Ph.D. in 2002 in Statistics from McMaster University. His research interests include order statistics, reliability theory, and analysis of censored data.

details.abstract: The likelihood equations based on a progressively Type-II censored sample from a Gaussian distribution do not provide explicit solutions in any situation except the complete sample case. This paper examines numerically the bias and mean square error of the MLE, and demonstrates that the probability coverages of the pivotal quantities (for location and scale parameters) based on asymptotic s-normality are unsatisfactory, and particularly so when the effective sample size is small. Therefore, this paper suggests using unconditional simulated percentage points of these pivotal quantities for constructing s-confidence intervals. An approximation of the Gaussian hazard function is used to develop approximate estimators which are explicit and are almost as efficient as the MLE in terms of bias and mean square error; however, the probability coverages of the corresponding pivotal quantities based on asymptotic s-normality are also unsatisfactory. A wide range of sample sizes and progressive censoring schemes are used in this study.

citations.title: Point and interval estimation for Gaussian distribution, based on progressively Type-II censored samples

context.text: Numerous articles in the literature have dealt with inference under Type-I and Type-II censoring for various parametric families of distributions; see [1] for details.
Reference [2] also discusses some numerical methods for obtaining the MLE of the parameters; see also [1].

references.title: Truncated and Censored Samples: Theory and Applications
references.text: A. C. Cohen, Truncated and Censored Samples: Theory and Applications, 1991, Marcel Dekker.

context.text: References [2], [3] are some of the earliest studies of a more general censoring scheme: Fix \$m\$ censoring times \$T_1,\, \ldots T_m\$.
Reference [2] discusses the estimation of parameters under this scheme for the Gaussian distribution.
Reference [2] discusses MLE under the assumption of Progressive Type-I censoring.
Reference [2] also discusses some numerical methods for obtaining the MLE of the parameters; see also [1].

references.title: Progressively censored samples in life testing
references.text: A. C. Cohen, "Progressively censored samples in life testing", Technometrics, vol. 5, pp. 327-329, 1963.

context.text: References [2], [3] are some of the earliest studies of a more general censoring scheme: Fix \$m\$ censoring times \$T_1,\, \ldots T_m\$.

references.title: Life testing and early failure
references.text: A. C. Cohen, "Life testing and early failure", Technometrics, vol. 8, pp. 539-549, 1966.

context.text: References [4]–[6] discuss inference for the Weibull and exponential distributions under Progressive Type-II censoring.

references.title: Exact three-order-statistic confidence bounds on reliable life for a Weibull model with progressive censoring
references.text: N. R. Mann, "Exact three-order-statistic confidence bounds on reliable life for a Weibull model with progressive censoring", J. Amer. Statist. Assoc., vol. 64, pp. 306-315, 1969.

context.text: References [4]–[5][6] discuss inference for the Weibull and exponential distributions under Progressive Type-II censoring.

references.title: Best linear invariant estimation for Weibull parameters under progressive censoring
references.text: N. R. Mann, "Best linear invariant estimation for Weibull parameters under progressive censoring", Technometrics, vol. 13, pp. 521-533, 1971.

context.text: References [4]–[6] discuss inference for the Weibull and exponential distributions under Progressive Type-II censoring.
Reference [6] derives explicit expressions for the BLUE of the parameters of the 1- and 2-parameter exponential distributions.

references.title: Interval estimation of parameters of life from progressively censored data
references.text: R. Viveros, N. Balakrishnan, "Interval estimation of parameters of life from progressively censored data", Technometrics, vol. 36, pp. 84-91, 1994.

links.abstract: This paper presents reliability sampling plans for the lognormal distribution based on progressively censored samples. In constructing these sampling plans, large-sample approximations to the best linear unbiased estimators of the location and scale parameters are used. For some selected progressive censoring schemes, reliability sampling plans are tabulated for p/sub /spl alpha// and p/sub /spl beta// to match MIL-STD-105. While in general, variable-sampling plans require smaller sample size wh...

context.text: Reference [7] discusses the construction of reliability sampling plans for the lognormal distribution based on progressively censored samples.

references.title: Reliability sampling plans for lognormal distribution, based on progressively-censored samples
references.text: U. Balasooriya, N. Balakrishnan, "Reliability sampling plans for lognormal distribution based on progressively-censored samples", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 49, pp. 199-203, 2000.

context.text: For an exhaustive list of references and further details on progressive censoring, see [8].

The MSE of these estimators are comparable to the variances of the BLUE in [8].
Also, a study [8] for the BLUE reveals a similar result for the optimal censoring scheme.

references.title: Progressive Censoring: Theory, Methods, and Applications
references.text: N. Balakrishnan, R. Aggarwala, Progressive Censoring: Theory Methods and Applications, 2000, Birkhauser.

context.text: Some approximate solutions are discussed in [9].
It is important to mention that a similar approximate MLE has been presented in [9].
First, [9] considers progressively Type-I censored samples; then the approximation is developed by considering a random interval that is likely to cover \$(T_i-\mu)/\sigma\$ (defined in Section II).
Thus the approximate MLE in [9] is different (not based on properties of uniform order statistics).

references.title: Robust Inference
references.text: M. L. Tiku, W. Y. Tan, N. Balakrishnan, Robust Inference, 1986, Marcel Dekker.

context.text: From [10]:\$U_{i:m:n}\$ is the corresponding order statistic #\$i\$ of a progressively Type-II censored sample from the \$U(0,\, 1)\$ distribution.
Type-II censored samples were generated progressively from the standard Gaussian distribution using the algorithm in [10].

references.title: A simple simulational algorithm for generating progressive type-II censored samples
references.text: N. Balakrishnan, R. A. Sandhu, "A simple simulational algorithm for generating progressive type-II censored samples", Amer. Statist., vol. 49, pp. 229-230, 1995.
